awd_titl_txt: IRES: US-Estonia Research Partnership in Reconstructing Past Climate Dynamics
awd_abstract_narration:
Records of past climate variability from northern Europe will improve our ability to predict future environmental changes in the North Atlantic region. This IRES project will partner with premier universities in Estonia to train students in interdisciplinary field-based environmental science methods in order to develop archives of past temperature and precipitation changes from the Baltic region. Each year the project will involve initial orientations, 5 weeks of international summer field and lab-based instruction, follow-up laboratory work at home institutions during the academic year, and conference presentations in the spring. A total of 4 students (undergraduate and graduate) and 1 in-service public science teacher (RET) each year will be recruited, and all the undergraduate participants will be from 2 year colleges in northern Illinois. Students from underrepresented groups will be targeted, and at least one undergraduate student per year will be from a non-STEM background.

This project will apply a multi-proxy approach to explore the timing and causes of historic climate variability in northern Europe. Student projects will be interrelated to develop a better understanding of how shifting Northern Hemisphere temperatures and mean-state conditions of the North Atlantic Ocean have influenced the climate dynamics of the eastern Baltic region. These datasets will serve as predictive tools for future variation across the Northern Hemisphere. Student projects will focus on lake sediment geochemistry (stable isotopes - ?18O and ?13C), paleoecology, and biology as tools to reconstruct past climate conditions. The educational goals are to: 1) Engage students in societally-relevant scientific topics to promote interest in STEM fields; 2) Mentor participants in state-of-the-art scientific research methods to better prepare them for STEM majors, careers, and advanced degrees; 3) Develop participants written and oral communication skills through mentoring and public presentations; and 4) Recruit underrepresented minority students and in-service public science teachers to promote diversity and sustainable impacts in public schools. The program components, project team, and participant experience will be rigorously evaluated by a geoscience education research specialist.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Records of past climate variability from northern Europe will improve our ability to predict future environmental changes in the North Atlantic region. To this end, this project established a research partnership and exchange with scholars in Estonia, focused on training students in state-of-the-art environmental science methods. This project partnered with premier universities in Estonia to train students in interdisciplinary field-based science methods in order to develop archives of environmental changes from the Baltic region.

Each year the project involved initial orientations, 5 weeks of international summer field and lab-based instruction, follow-up laboratory work at home institutions during the academic year, and conference presentations. Each summer, approximately 5 students were selected, with roughly half being graduate students and the others were first- or second-year undergraduates. All the undergraduate participants were from 2 year colleges in northern Illinois, and most were from underrepresented groups from non-STEM fields.

The primary focus of IRES projects is student training and mentoring that is led by international research partners. The bulk of the mentoring was done by a former PhD student from Estonia, Mariliis Eensalu, under the supervision of the lead PI and faculty members in northern Europe. The bulk of the research objectives became part of Mariliis’ doctoral dissertation that she successfully defended at the culmination of the project in summer, 2024. From this dissertation, 3 chapters have been published in peer-reviewed journals with a fourth chapter that will also be published soon. Much of this published work includes IRES participants as co-authors.

The focus of Mariliis’ dissertation explored lake sediment records of past climate and environmental variability in northern Europe. Through these efforts, she trained IRES students in field and lab-based methods for extracting and analyzing geological, biological and ecological records. Several researchers from across northern Europe also helped with the mentoring efforts by sharing their expertise in various scientific methods.

A Master’s student, Max Boes, completed a thesis project involving lake sediment records from Estonia. His efforts reconstructed past precipitation changes that aid in our understanding of climate dynamics on a range of time scales in the Northern Hemisphere.

The lead PI also published a paper with some of the IRES participants. This paper focused on peatland records of environmental change over the last ~4000 years. This work helps improve our understanding of how the carbon cycle is sensitive to environmental changes on longer timescales and provides perspective for future potential changes due to anthropogenic warming.

Multiple outreach and public engagement efforts took place during the duration of the project. The PI gave talks to several community colleges and universities in the area, emphasizing the importance of engaging undergraduates in research projects.

During the final year of the IRES project, much of the research effort contributed to the NSF-sponsored program known as The Global Learning and Observations to Benefit the Environment (GLOBE). This program provides training modules for students at multiple levels. GLOBE also provides an infrastructure for doing citizen science and working with primary and secondary schools abroad. Through GLOBE, the IRES students also worked with a local school in Estonia, as they built a deployed an automated weather station. This weather station is still in use and is being incorporated in science classes at a high school in Viljandi county, Estonia.

Ultimately, this IRES project helped numerous students advance their education and be able to go on to more advanced studies and/or find jobs in environmental fields. Researchers on both continents also gained valuable knowledge about dynamics related to shifting environments and climate change.
